Euroclear, the Belgian institution managing frozen Russian assets that will 'not rule out' suing the EU
subhead: Euroclear, a little-known but central player in Europe's financial system, holds €193 billion in frozen Russian assets that, since the invasion of Ukraine, have drawn intense scrutiny. Its director general, Valérie Urbain, warns that confiscation – illegal under international law – would weaken Europe's position.

Ten years after terror hit, Paris has (re)claimed itself as the center of the world
French winegrowers set to protest as industry faces crisis
subhead: Winegrowers from southern France are planning a major protest on Saturday, November 15. With unpredictable weather, rising costs and plummeting sales, the industry is demanding emergency measures to avoid a wave of business closures and to pressure both the French government and the European Union in Brussels to act.

title: 'We hunt for bodies': Ukraine funeral home 'mafia' thrives on war
subhead: Ukraine's funeral services are not immune to corruption. A scandal that has predated the war but been largely kept quiet has accelerated over the past three years. Bereaved families are the primary victims.

title: Jézabel Couppey-Soubeyran: 'What if the stock market euphoria over AI is just a bubble within the larger financial bubble?'
subhead: In her column, the economist points out that the financial markets have been inflated by decades of monetary policy tailored to their needs. She warns that it is the collapse of this broader bubble, not just that of artificial intelligence, which should be of greatest concern.

title: 'Jewelry is easy to steal and circulate': When gems vanish without a trace
subhead: The Louvre heist has highlighted just how difficult it is for investigators to recover stolen jewelry. Every year, around 100 jewelry professionals in France fall victim to break-ins. Most of the time, the loot remains untraceable, laundered, transformed or sometimes even abandoned.

COP30: 'Those drawn to China's environmental push should keep a few facts in mind'
subhead: China is presenting itself as the leader in the renewable energy economy, positioning itself against the United States, which remains entrenched in fossil fuels. Yet, this transition has proven misleading, writes Pascal Riché in his column for Le Monde.

title: 'Delhi is no longer livable': Deadly pollution in Indian capital claims more than 17,000 lives each year
subhead: Millions of firecrackers set off during the Hindu festival of Diwali at the end of October have worsened the already extreme fine particle pollution engulfing the megacity. Every winter, Delhi's 30 million residents face a toxic nightmare, while blistering heat waves strike the city each summer.

title: 'Ukraine was our bulwark against Putin, now it is his springboard'
subhead: Is Europe ready for war? Apart from Finland, the answer is no, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.
